column32:
- when clicking through the animation clips before the game starts, it showed a black screen between clips
- i believe incorporating a space bar feature to click through the clips would be more effective for the user 
- the clips seemed to be lower quality (more pixelated than the game) 
- it would be nice if the animation of the clip didnt stop at a certain point and continued until the user clicks to the next scene (animation flows better)

column27: I would like to see more game-based learning approaches, but perhaps combined with conventional teaching methods, so that there's more of a balance. That way, classes can be more fun and engaging but I feel that more content can be taught with conventional methods. So, I think a balance of the two would be ideal!
column31: It was really accessible for me. Everything in the game was easy to use and explained well.

column27: I think so. Being blunt, the university grind sucks and it's hard to find the motivation to keep pushing through lecture after lecture after lecture. Having something fun like this that breaks up the monotony I think is a great way to alleviate a little bit of that university burn out and revitalize some of that motivation to do the work. For me especially, I think this could be a helpful study tool because I am very easily distracted by anything even marginally more interesting than staring at a textbook, so having something more engaging to study with would be really beneficial.
column31: I'm not the best person to assess accessibility, but generally the game didn't feel terribly difficult. It does require some degree of motor skill, but any game will. I think it's probably pretty good all things considered, but again, I'm not a good person to assess this.

column27: yes, it would let me have more motivation for class.

Before the game was explained by Dr da Silva, I wasn't really sure what each molecule was. Maybe it would be more useful at the start of the game to label each molecule so that it sticks better.
